posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
We’re running on thin margins with battery capacity this year. When our robot is sitting on the field for 15 minutes waiting for the match to start, this isn’t helping us when we have two Limelights pulling a couple amps that whole time. I’d like to power them from an external battery pack instead, as allowed by R602. image 943×212 12.7 KB

image 943×212 12.7 KB

image 943×212 12.7 KB

Is anyone doing this? What hardware are you using? Any recommendations? Can I use something like a 2-cell camera battery (Sony NP-F-970) or would that not be legal because it’s not integral to a camera?

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
Given the limit of 5V power and COTS (USB) cable, pretty sure you can’t legally power a limelight, as it wants 12v power from either 2 custom wires and or POE.

You can do a Orange/Raspberry PI camera setup from a USB power source with the rules.

posts.name: Tyson Whelan
posts.cooked: My team is actually doing this to power our camera system, but we are running PhotonVision on an OrangePi 5+ instead of limelight. According to this page in the Limelight documentation, Limelights can run off of as low as 4.5V but the LEDs need at least 7. If you are using the LEDs this will not be possible, but otherwise I’d assume it would work. I’d recommend doing some testing with them running off of a battery pack to see how they hold up before actually committing to this idea.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Drakxii:

Given the limit of 5V power and COTS (USB) cable, pretty sure you can’t legally power a limelight, as it wants 12v power from either 2 custom wires

As I read the rules, it seems to me that you could use a COTS USB 5V-to-12V step up cable to power your limelight.

[EDIT] No idea if the battery pack would have sufficient power to do so, just that it seems to meet the letter of the rules

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
john3928:

COTS USB 5V-to-12V step up cable

But could you use it “unmodified”?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: It seems that these cables typically end in a male barrel jack, so you would need to use a second (unmodified) COTS cable to complete the connection.  For example: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/tensility-international-corp/10-02248/6412283
